journey_steps.description: Potential customers learn about British Airways, either by word of mouth, advertisements, or online research.
Customers start gathering information about flight services for their travel, including routes, schedules, and pricing. They may visit the British Airways website, apps, or other travel platforms.
Customers evaluate different options based on their preferences. They consider factors like flight timings, reviews, luggage policies, and extra services offered by British Airways.
Upon comparison and consideration, customers decide to book their travel with British Airways if the offerings meet their preferences.
Customers go through the booking process which involves selecting the flight, adding passenger details, reserving seats, and processing payment.
Customers prepare for their journey after the booking confirmation. This may involve packing, checking flight schedule for any updates, and arranging airport transportation.
Customers check-in online or at the airport. They collect boarding passes, clear security checks and board their designated British Airways flight.
Customers experience in-flight services. The quality of these services like seating comfort, food quality, and treatment by the cabin crew can influence their overall impression of British Airways.
Upon reaching their destination, customers collect their checked baggage (if any). They may also need assistance with lost/delayed baggage or connecting flights.
British Airways may reach out to customers with a thank you note or to collect feedback. Customers may also interact with customer service to resolve any issues encountered during their journey.
